title.rendered: The “for dummies” explanation of how NFTs work that has gone viral

content.rendered:
For a few months, concepts such as cryptocurrencies, digital art or NFTs have fully entered our reality, despite the fact that their operation leaves many of the people who have heard or read about them in doubt.

Read also Andrea Amantegui Guezala

Some tech gurus say they are the future, while others see them as a modern scam dressed up as a revolution. The entry into this world of personalities as relevant as Gerard Piqué or the popular youtuber Willyrex, have made many young people interested in this technology and see it as an opportunity to earn money. Something that has generated concern and concern in many users of social networks.

But what are NFTs really and what practical application do they have? The Non Fungible Token (non-fungible token) are nothing more than certificates of authenticity of digital works. A market that has exploded thanks to millionaire acquisitions such as Everydays: The first 5000 daysfrom the digital artist Beeple, for something 58 million euros or the sale of the first tweet of Jack Dorsey (founder of Twitter) for 1.7 million euros.

Also read AFP AFP

The proof to prove that a digital work belongs to you is given by the reliability provided by the blockchain technology called blockchain. The same system used by cryptocurrencies like bitcoin to validate transactions.

But owning a digital work does not prevent other users from viewing it and even downloading it. The only difference is that the owner has a digital certificate that accredits him as the owner of the works and this is recorded in the block chain deeds.

Thus, we can determine that the intention of the NFTs is to provide value to unique works of the 2.0 world to be collected, sold or exchanged. Their practical application is the stuff of constant debate on social media, and Twitter user @Angel_monium has further ignited it by posting a screenshot of a YouTube comment explaining how NFTs work “for dummies.”

Explaining how NFTs work for dummies pic.twitter.com/DGHnMOzgON

— 🖤 ᴬⁿᵍᵉˡᵐᵒⁿⁱᵘᵐ 🤍 ₓᵢₒₙ 💜 (@Angel_monium) December 14, 2021

The author of the comment ironically compares NFTs with companies that charge for giving away or naming stars: “Has something changed when you bought it? Only, in some database, it says that you paid to call a star like you now ex girlfriend”.

User reaction

Unsurprisingly, this comparison has inflamed the tempers of NFT advocates, who believe it to be short-sighted, and emboldened its detractors, who simply conceive of it as mere speculation.

Justifying me that NFTs are good and reliable because of the Blockchain is like justifying me that banks are good and reliable because they have security guards.

— DrJetlag (@DrJetlag) December 14, 2021

The problem is that this purchase does not guarantee exclusivity over that work of art in that it is infinitely replicable in an exact way, it only gives you ownership over the lines of code that say it is your property, the utilities do not go beyond the mere speculation

– Adri (@adrian_cordoba7) December 14, 2021

It seems that the debate is going on for a long time and that only time will give and take away reasons.
